habitat_description:
Toxostoma redivivum primarily inhabits dense chaparral (Grinnell, 1917; Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Wirtz, 1979; Garrett and Dunn, 1981; Soule et al., 1988; Laudenslayer et al., 1992; Cody, 2012) and similar shrub-dominated environments, including coastal sage scrub (Moriarty et al., 1985) and desert mixed scrub (Hanna, 1936; Arnold, 1937), but it can also be found in oak, pine, or pine-oak woodlands with high shrub cover (Grinnell, 1917; Verner and Boss, 1980; Moriarty et al., 1985; Verner and Ritter, 1985; Verner et al., 1997; Cody, 2012) as well as in riparian shrubs (Anthony, 1895; Grinnell, 1917; Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Linsdale, 1947; Garrett and Dunn, 1981; Laudenslayer et al., 1992; Cody, 2012). The species has also been documented in residential areas and parks with ample shrub cover (Sargent, 1940; Laudenslayer et al., 1992; Cody, 2012).

California thrashers require dense shrubs (Verner and Boss, 1980; Cody, 2012), and are not found in depauperate environments, such as recently burned shrubland (Wirtz, 1979; Moriarty et al., 1985) or grazed sites (Verner and Ritter, 1985; Verner et al., 1997). The species also avoids forests with dense tree canopy (Verner and Boss, 1980).

T. redivivum nest two to six feet above the ground, in shrubs (Arnold, 1937; Grinnell, 1917; Hanna, 1936) and occasionally in a small, isolated tree (Grinnell, 1917). They forage on and near the ground, beneath dense chaparral (Grinnell, 1917; Soule et al., 1988).

The species is found at elevations from near sea level up to ~2000 m (Zeiner et al., 1990; see also: Willett, 1933; Grinnell and Miller, 1944).
